awd_titl_txt: CPS: Breakthrough: Robust Team-Triggered Coordination for Real-Time Control of Networked Cyber-Physical Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The aim of this project is to lay down the foundations of a novel approach to real-time control of networked cyber-physical systems (CPS) that leverages their cooperative nature.  Most networked controllers are not implementable over embedded digital computer systems because they rely on continuous time or synchronous executions that are costly to enforce. These assumptions are unrealistic when faced with the cyber-physical world, where the interaction between computational and physical components is multiplex, information acquisition is subject to error and delay, and agent schedules are asynchronous. Even without implementation obstacles, the periodic availability of information leads to a wasteful use of resources. Tuning controller execution to the task at hand offers the potential for great savings in communication, sensing, and actuation.  The goal of this project is to bring this opportunity to fruition by combining event- and self-triggered control ideas into a unified approach that inherits the best of both models. The key conceptual novelty is for agents to make promises to one another about their future states and warn each other if they later decide to break them. The information provided by promises allows agents to autonomously determine when fresh information is needed, resulting in an efficient network performance.

Networked cyber-physical systems are transforming the way society interacts with the physical world. Advances in this field are extending the range of human capabilities in an increasing number of areas with high societal and economic impact, such as smart energy, intelligent transportation, advanced manufacturing, health technology, and the environment.  This project contributes to the science and technology of cyber-physical systems by developing a novel principled approach for networked systems to operate efficiently and cope with the sources of uncertainty present in real-word applications.  The potential benefits are real-time operation in a wide range of application domains of cooperative cyber-physical systems with a superior level of efficiency and robustness than currently possible. The project promises to contribute to the training of a new generation of engineering students at UC San Diego with the skills necessary to deal with this type of multi-faceted systems and applications.  The plan includes undergraduate student involvement in research, graduate supervision and curriculum development, outreach to high-school students, retention of minorities in STEM disciplines, and broad dissemination activities.

por.por_cntn:
Cyber-physical systems can successfully achieve their objective while tolerating varying degrees of uncertainty in their knowledge of the environment, other elements of the network, or the adversary.  Most controllers, however, are not truly implementable over real physical systems with embedded components because they are designed under idealistic assumptions.  Such assumptions are unrealistic when faced with the complexity of the cyber-physical world: the interaction between computational and physical components is multiplex, information transmission and acquisition is subject to delay and loss, and individual systems operate asynchronously. Even without considering the implementation challenges, the continuous or periodic availability of information often leads to a wasteful use of the communication and sensor network resources.  Tuning the controller execution to the task at hand offers the potential for great savings in communication, sensing, and actuator effort.  The challenge then lies in implementing these networked controllers in real time, while preserving their guarantees about task completion and ensuring their robustness against the multiple sources of disruption present in the real world. At the same time, the challenge also concerns endowing individual cyber-physical systems with sufficient autonomy to allow them to determine what and when information is needed to perform the desired task with a desired quality of service.

On the intellectual merit side, the main project outcome is a novel, unified approach for networked cyber-physical systems that seeks to combine the best of the strengths of event- and self-triggered control.  In the context of real-time control of embedded systems, approaches based on agent triggers provide a sound solution to address these implementation issues. In event- triggered control, the focus is on detecting relevant events during the network execution from the point of view of task completion and trigger specific agent actions. In self-triggered control, instead, the emphasis is on developing criteria that rely only on the information available to individual agents to schedule future actions. Event-triggered control results in better performance but is not implementable over fully distributed networked scenarios because of the need for continuous availability of information to check the triggers. Self-triggered control is more easily amenable to distributed implementation but results in conservative executions because of over-approximation by individual agents about the state of the environment and the network.The key conceptual novelty of the project is for agents to make promises to one another about their future states and warn each other if they later decide to break them. The research of the project has developed this approach in multiple scenarios, including privacy preservation, human-robot collaboration, and distributed algorithmic solutions to problems with global constraints.

On the broader impacts side, the research of this project has contributed to the science and technology of cyber-physical systems by developing a unified, transformative paradigm to synthesize novel high-confidence strategies for networked systems. The project has opened up a new research direction that builds on existing triggered approaches for controller implementation to provide implementable coordination algorithms with certification guarantees, superior performance, and capable of coping with dynamic environments, uncertainty, and evolving task specifications.  The research has made an impact in the training of a new generation of scientists and engineers at UC San Diego, who have acquired multidisciplinary knowledge and skills necessary to deal with these complex networked cyber-physical systems.  Specific outcomes include supervision of graduate and postdoctoral students, involvement of undergraduate students in research, one-on-one mentoring of undergraduate students, outreach to incoming freshman and transfer students, and lab tours to high school, and middle school to promote STEM disciplines.  The results have been disseminated through conference and journal publications, online availability of preprints and publications, including the CPS virtual organization, invited research talks delivered at top institutions, invited plenary talks at professional research meetings, and hardware demonstrations at robotic workshops.
